comments:
I unpacked the M6 install over the M5 install.
When I try to launch the app with the following command
C:\eclipse\eclipse.exe -data c:\anikolaev\work\workspace -vm C:\j2sdk1.4.1_03
\jre\bin\javaw

Eclipse fails to start with the following exception in the log file:

java.version=1.4.1_03
java.vendor=Sun Microsystems Inc.
BootLoader constants: OS=win32, ARCH=x86, WS=win32, NL=en_US
Command-line arguments: -os win32 -ws win32 -arch x86 -data 
c:\anikolaev\work\workspace -install file:C:/eclipse/
!ENTRY com.objectlearn.jdt.j2ee 1 0 Dec 23, 2003 08:40:57.625
!MESSAGE Creating server definition manager
[C:/eclipse/plugins/com.objectlearn.jdt.j2ee/]
!SESSION ----------------------------------------------------------------------
!ENTRY org.eclipse.core.launcher 4 0 Dec 23, 2003 08:44:28.234
!MESSAGE Exception launching the Eclipse Platform:
!STACK
java.lang.IllegalStateException: Unable to acquire application service
	at org.eclipse.core.runtime.adaptor.EclipseStarter.run
(EclipseStarter.java:84)
	at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method)
	at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke
(NativeMethodAccessorImpl.java:39)
	at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke
(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:25)
	at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:324)
	at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.basicRun(Main.java:279)
	at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.run(Main.java:742)
	at org.eclipse.core.launcher.Main.main(Main.java:581)


Reverting back to M5, i.e. unpacking over M6 fixes the problem.

Regards,
Antoan Nikolaev

PS This prevents me of using M6 in general.

Eclipse installs should not be unzipped overtop each other.

See the "Upgrading Eclipse" Task in the workbench user guide:
http://help.eclipse.org/help21/topic/org.eclipse.platform.doc.user/tasks/tasks-2.htm

Try installing the M6 build in a new directory and then pointing to your
workspace using the -data flag.

That did the trick, but wouldn't be better if eclipse can be upgraded? Are you 
guys planning to add support for that? It is major annoyance to have to 
redeploy all your plugins from scratch.

Regards,
Antoan Nikolaev

PS You guys are doing an amazing job!

The way to upgrade Eclipse in-place is through the update site. Sometimes it
gets a little confused when unzipping over-top another install due to
conflicting plug-in ids, etc etc.

As for adding your third-party plug-ins to your new install, I would recommend
using the "links" directory. Check out the link above. The section at the bottom
of the page makes a reference to it.
